Verified Deep Learning [CS 839 / Spring 2020]   Aws Albarghouthi   Office hrs: Tue, 1300-1415, CS 6363   TA: Swati Anand, sanand24@wisc.edu

Deep neural networks are fragile and their behaviors are often surprising. In many settings, we need to provide formal guarantees on the safety, security, correctness, or robustness of neural networks. This course covers foundational ideas from formal verification and their application to deep learning .
The couse is based on chapters from the instructor's on the subject and research papers from machine learning and verification.
Overview of verified deep learning   Tuesday chapter 1 / slides   Thursday chapter 2
Correctness properties of neural networks   Tuesday chapter 3 / Hoare's classic paper / Floyd's paper / Turing's obscure paper   Thursday chapter 4 / see also slides from Dillig's course
Logical encodings of neural networks   Tuesday chapter 5 / see also encodings of traditional programs   Thursday cancelled
Encodings and decision procedures   Tuesday chapter 5, continued / see Z3 tutorial   Thursday chapter 6 / see abstract DPPL paper
SMT solving   Tuesday ‚úàÔ∏è Aws out of town for a PC meeting Tuesday   Thursday chapter 6 / see abstract DPPL paper
Neural - network specialized theory solvers   Tuesday chapter 7 / see paper from Dutertre & de Moura   Thursday chapter 7 / see Reluplex paper
A taste of abstract interpretation   Tuesday chapter 8 / Lifting neural networks to operate on sets   Thursday chapter 8 / Interval abstraction of neural operations
Advanced abstract domains for neural networks   Tuesday chapter 9 / Zonotope abstraction / see DeepZ paper   Thursday chapter 9 / Polyhedra abstraction / see Stars and DeepPoly papers
üå∑Spring break
More on abstraction   Tuesday tuning virtual lectures + asn 2 preview   Thursday Joint abstraction / see k - ReLU paper
Abstract training   Tuesday Abstract training / see DiffAI and IBP papers (IBP is an easier read)   Thursday Randomized smoothing + NLP / see Cohen et al. and Huang et al.
Verified RL   Tuesday Invariants and NNs / see Zhu et al.   Thursday MDPs and verification / see Zhu et al.
TBD   Tuesday   Thu
Project presentations   Tuesday presentations   Thursday presentations
Project presentations   Tuesday presentations   Thursday presentations + farewell
Grade distribution:
75% project (mid March review 15%, mid April review 15%, paper 30%, 15% presentation)   25% assignments (5% participation + 3 assignments)
Project details:
Find project partner and choose project   Create GitHub repository in CS839 organization   Weekly update README.md with new developments, problems, etc.
